entry.title: Resilience in the face of thirst: Trucking water in war-ravaged Gaza
entry.summary: In Gaza, where lack of access to water is an existential threat, Ibrahim Alloush stands out as an unsung hero, providing a lifeline to the thirsty people of the Strip.

entry.title: The â€˜chinamperosâ€™ have provided Mexico City with food for generations. Do they have a future?
entry.summary: Xochimilco, nestled in the heart of Mexico City, is home to the â€˜chinamperos,â€™ farmers who have used indigenous techniques to grow food for centuries. Today, their way of life is under threat from environmental degradation, urban expansion and climate change.

entry.title: 7 must-try adventures on mainland Greece
entry.summary:
The submerged lost city of Pavlopetri lies off the Peloponnese coast. Plot an active break, whether you want to climb up a mountain rife with myths or swim down to a lost city.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
One of the best ways to explore mainland Greece is under your own steam, through the myriad activities on offer here. There are opportunities to don a mask and flippers and snorkel over an ancient submerged city; to climb Mount Olympus, the fabled home of Zeus, king of the gods; to leap into a boat and whitewater-raft down a 7.5-mile-long gorge; and to ski through the quiet backcountry of its Peloponnese mountain range.
Created during a 1960s hydroelectric project to dam four rivers, Greeceâ€™s biggest artificial lake is a fjord-likâ€¦

entry.title: Going to Japan? Here's how to collect station stamps
entry.summary: Japanese station stamps, or eki stamps, can be collecting in most train stations and many tourist attractions in Japan. Japanese eki stamps (station stamps) are a charming feature of Japanese railway culture. Beloved by visitors and oshi-tetsu (train-stamp nerds) alike, collecting them as you make your way around Japan is easy and free, and results in a unique and lasting record of your journey. Hereâ€™s everything you need to know about creating your own eki stamp collection. This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). Now ubiquitous in many of Japanâ€™s 9,000 stations, the first eki stamp appeared in 1931 at Fukui station near the Sea of Japan coast, where stationmaster Kanichi Tominaga hit upon the idea of a commemorative stamp after a casual conveâ€¦

entry.title: We tried out Pedro Pascalâ€™s â€˜The Last of Usâ€™ jacket. Hereâ€™s our full review.
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
On April 13, the second season of HBOâ€™s The Last of Us picks up the harrowing journey that Joel and Ellie (played by Pedro Pascal and Bella Ramsey) take across a world decimated by a runaway fungal virus. Also returning? Joelâ€™s Huckberry Flint and Tinder Flannel Lined Waxed Trucker Jacket thatâ€”like the showâ€”has become a real-world hit, selling out everywhere.Â
Thatâ€™s understandableâ€”after all, any jacket that can stand up to cordyceps-riddled zombieâ€¦

entry.title: This was a hotspot for great white sharksâ€”then they vanished
entry.summary:
Built like a torpedo with rows of terrifying 2.5-inch teeth, the worldâ€™s largest predatory shark is an intimidating sight. So intimidating that some might think an ocean without great white sharks (Carcharodon carcharias) would be a good thing. But their loss causes a ripple effect that transforms the entire ecosystem.
A new study in Frontiers in Marine Science shows what happens when sharks vanish. Seal Island, off South Africa's False Bay was once a great white hotspotâ€”one of the few places on Earth where the sharks could be seen surging out of the water to capture prey.
â€œIt was air Jaws,â€ says marine ecologist Neil Hammerschlag, executive director of the Shark Research Foundation Inc. and a coauthor on the new study. â€œI don't think there's anything more remarkable in nature thâ€¦

entry.title: 5 places with the most incredible running trails in the world
entry.summary: Runners competing in the Marakez Pyramids Half Marathon in Cairo, Egypt. Imagine running with a view of the Pyramids of Giza or inside the valley of a dormant volcano. The new book 100 Runs of a Lifetime has a must-visit destination for anyone who loves a good runâ€”no matter your skill level. From the Pyramids of Giza in Egypt to the PouÄkai Circuit in New Zealand to HaleakalÄ National Park in Maui, there are many incredible running trails all over the world. The new National Geographic book, 100 Runs of a Lifetime, written by Bart Yasso (who served as the chief running officer for 30 years at Runner's World magazine), explores all of these destinations and more. Here are five running trails that are worth traveling for. Egypt Cairo is a popular destination for trâ€¦

entry.title: Countries reach historic deal to cut shipping emissions
entry.summary: After years of intense negotiations, countries on Friday reached a landmark deal to cut greenhouse gas emissions from global shipping, setting mandatory fuel standards and introducing an industry-wide carbon pricing mechanism.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar: Military strikes persist amid earthquake response efforts
entry.summary: Military operations continue in Myanmar despite ceasefires declared after the recent earthquake that killed more than 3,600 people, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo crisis: Children subjected to deliberate, systemic sexual violence
entry.summary: Sexual violence against children in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) has reached staggering proportions, with the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) reporting thousands of new cases in just two months â€“ evidence that itâ€™s being used as a systemic weapon of war and deliberate terror tactic.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: US tariffs move could see three per cent fall in global trade, says top UN economist
entry.summary: Global trade could shrink by three per cent as a result of the United Statesâ€™ new tariff measures which in the longer term could reshape and boost as-yet untapped regional commercial links, a top UN economist confirmed on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN refugee agency calls for greater investment in Syrian returnees
entry.summary: Roughly 400,000 Syrians have returned home from the region since the fall of the Assad regime last December, while more than a million internally displaced persons (IDPs) have gone back to their communities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN rights office condemns Israeli buffer zone plan
entry.summary: The UN human rights office said on Friday it fears that Israel may intend to permanently remove civilians in Gaza as part of an expanded buffer zone, amid evacuations orders and escalating bombardment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war has created suffering of â€˜industrial proportionsâ€™, aid agencies warn
entry.summary: Two years since Sudanâ€™s brutal conflict began, UN agencies warned that famine is spreading and civilians of all ages continue to suffer shocking abuse, including rape and gang rape.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Do crossword puzzles really keep your brain sharp?
entry.summary:
An elderly person works on a crossword puzzle. These games can help keep the brain engagedâ€”but studies show other habits, like exercise and education, play a far greater role in preventing cognitive decline. Theyâ€™ve long been seen as a way to prevent cognitive declineâ€”but experts say the real key to brain health goes far beyond word games.
Ask almost anyone how to stay mentally sharp in old age; chances are someone will bring up crossword puzzles. Alongside Sudoku and word searches, these games have long been seen as â€œworkoutsâ€ for the brain. In fact, a 2020 study published in Frontiers in Human Neuroscience found these kinds of puzzles are among the most frequently engaged-in activities for brain training and cognitive benefits.
But how did this belief become so widespread? Aâ€¦

entry.title: Alex Ovechkinâ€™s spot on the ice and shot preference
entry.summary: Alex Ovechkin passed Wayne Gretzkyâ€™s all-time goals record with number 895. For Theâ€¦ Tags: Alex Ovechkin, Athletic, hockey, sports

entry.title: Follow the divine topography of this Greek pilgrimage for monks
entry.summary:
The Rousanou Monastery was founded in the 14th century and is one of six still in use in the Meteora region. The region of Meteora combines outlandish topography and improbable architecture to divine effect.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As the sun sinks towards the serrated horizon of the distant Pindus Mountains, the assembled congregation grows quiet. There are perhaps 40 people gathered here, each occupying their own smooth knuckle of the lofty outcrop. Some have been present an hour or more, watching the day slowly drain from this extraordinary landscape. Others, such as myself, a matter of minutes â€” fortuitously passing Meteoraâ€™s most celebrated sunset spot as dusk closes in.
Itâ€™s quite the vantage point: all around, thrusting uâ€¦

entry.title: How Middle Eastern Data Outlets Use Data to Challenge Narratives and Advance Accountability

entry.title: Who is General Tsoâ€”and why does he have his own chicken dish?
entry.summary:
This iconic chicken dish was created for an American generalâ€”but named after a Chinese one. While the entrÃ©e was originally created in Taiwan, the recipe was actually specifically crafted for American eaters from the very start.
For the past fifty years, few dishes have defined Chinese-American cuisine quite like General Tsoâ€™s chicken. With its glistening, deep-fried crunch and sticky, sweet-savory glaze, itâ€™s become a staple on takeout menus across the United States.
But the dish was never meant to reflect traditional Chinese cooking. Although it originated in Taiwan, General Tsoâ€™s chicken was purposefully crafted to seduce the American palate from the very beginning.
(Peking duck: the complex history of a Chinese classic.)
The original version of General Tsoâ€™s câ€¦

entry.title: Was Cyrus the Great really a tolerant conqueror?
entry.summary: The Achaemenid kings of Persia ruled between the sixth and fourth centuries B.C., but much of what we know about them today comes from Greek rather than Persian sources. The various Greek authors who wrote about the Persians tended to depict them as decadent and weak-willed, ruled by a series of self-styled great kings. Persian culture was often contrasted with the austerity of Athens and Sparta. The stories of Persian kings that have filtered down through Greek works of philosophy, history, and plays mix firsthand observations with a large dose of fiction and fantasy. It should be remembered that the Greeks saw the might of Persia as a huge threat. For half a century they were engaged in the Greco-Persian wars (499-449 B.C.), fighting to keep that threat at bay, and this enmity shaped howâ€¦

entry.title: An insiderâ€™s guide to Nantes
entry.summary:
Set on Franceâ€™s Loire river, roughly 30 miles before it meets the Atlantic Ocean, the colourful city of Nantes is a cultural and artistic hub with a whimsical spirit. With contemporary art installations around every corner and several innovative museums, the city's creative side is prominent, while its Breton identity also remains strong â€” in the 15th century, Nantes was the seat of the dukes of Brittany, before the independent kingdom became part of France in 1532.
Even the cityâ€™s industrial past is treated with an artistic reverence â€” on the site of its former shipyards on the Ãle de Nantes (an island on the Loire river), you'll find Les Machines de lâ€™Ã®le, a collection of mechanical creations, including a 40ft-tall elephant that carries passengers around the concourse and sprays watâ€¦

entry.title: Why do birds sing so loudly in spring? Itâ€™s the â€˜dawn chorusâ€™
entry.summary:
As spring begins, so does a fresh song at daybreak, unique to the season. Just before the sun rises, birds start singing their melodies, creating a chirpy symphony.Â
This phenomenon is known as the dawn chorus, and itâ€™s special for a number of reasons: There are more birds singing at this time of year, and they also sing more often. This energetic burst of birdsong is often louder than usual too. The dawn chorusâ€™ early morning explosion of sounds has even inspired multipleÂ poemsÂ andÂ songs.Â
â€œIt's the epitome of spring,â€ says Jordan E. Rutter, an ornithologist at the American Bird Conservancy. After the long and cold winter, â€œall of a sudden you have this influx of so many beautiful birds coming back and singing.â€
This harmony of birdsong at dawn happens during a fundamental â€¦

entry.title: Dust isnâ€™t just dirtâ€”itâ€™s full of â€˜forever chemicalsâ€™
entry.summary:
Dust may seem like a harmless nuisanceâ€”but experts say those tiny particles that are floating in the air or accumulating in clumps under your couch or on your windowsill may actually cause more harm than you think.
â€œMost people think dust is gross but I donâ€™t think people associate dust with the potential health harms it may contain,â€ says Tasha Stoiber, a senior scientist at the Environmental Working Group. â€œIt might not be peopleâ€™s number one cleaning priority.â€
But it should be high on the list of priorities because dust isnâ€™t just dirt. It contains a blend of various substances, including dead skin cells, hair fragments, pet dander, clothing and furniture fibers, dust mites, mold and fungi spores, microplastic particles, as well as allergens (such as pollen), bacteria, and soâ€¦

entry.title: Americans knew their booze was poisonedâ€”and drank it anyway
entry.summary:
When bluesman Ishman Bracey poured himself a drink in Jackson, Mississippi, he didnâ€™t know his luck had just run as dry as the nationâ€™s taps.
A couple of weeks later, his legs were tingling. With rumors of a polio surge going around, he rushed to the hospital. But it wasnâ€™t a virus. Heâ€™d been poisoned.
The cause? A government policy that made drinking alcohol not just illegalâ€”but lethal.Â
During Prohibition, not all alcohol was banned â€”Â just drinkable, non-medicinal alcohol. To prevent bootleggers from repurposing industrial alcohol, the U.S. government launched what it called the â€œNoble Experiment,â€ adding toxic chemicals like methanol and benzene to render it undrinkable. According to a New York Times headline at the time, the government planned to â€œdouble alcohol poison câ€¦

entry.title: These are the best waterproof pants, according to adventurers
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Outdoor adventures are full of thrilling, unexpected moments, from wildlife sightings and jaw-dropping viewsâ€”to surprise downpours. Being prepared for any weather is key.Â Â
â€œWaterproof pants are important because staying dry means staying warm,â€ says Jonathan Grenier, founder of Ungava Polar Eco-Tours, an ecotourism company based in sub-Arctic Quebec. When guiding groups, Grenier often spends long hours trekking or boating in unpredictable conditionâ€¦

entry.title: How this sleepy Southern town became an art lover's paradise
entry.summary:
Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art was designed by renowned architect Moshe Safdie. With a world-class art museum, 70 miles of hiking and biking trails, and a thriving culinary scene, Bentonville, Arkansas, has emerged as a must-visit family-friendly getaway.
Bentonville, Arkansas, has emerged as a lively artistic and culinary destination, driven by the influence of the renowned Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art. Thanks to this cultural influx, and with plenty to capture the attention of parents and children alike, it's also a perfect getaway for families.
This area has long been known as a masterpiece of wild, wooded beauty. Situated on a plateau among the Ozark Mountains, Bentonvilleâ€™s network of nearly 70 miles of trails within the city connect to 400 miles of mounâ€¦

entry.title: How a penguin 'massacre' led to new protections in Argentina
entry.summary:
As spring turns to summer in the southern hemisphere, the Punta Tombo Natural Protected Area on Argentinaâ€™s central coast comes alive, with the chicks of some 180,000 pairs of nesting Magellanic penguins braying and peeping 24/7.
That penguin-palooza was nearing a crescendo in November 2021 when tragedy struck. A local rancher named Ricardo La Regina, then 33, intentionally drove a backhoe through nesting grounds just north of Punta Tombo, home to the worldâ€™s second-largest Magellanic penguin colony and part of the UNESCOâ€™s Patagonia Azul Biosphere Reserve. An estimated 175 nests were crushed and more than 100 penguins killed in what the Argentine press dubbed the â€œPunta Tombo Penguin Massacre.â€
But after a historic court case, some surprising good has come from the disaster, incâ€¦

(D1 è¯»å–å¤åˆ¶é€šè¿‡å°†è¯»å–æŸ¥è¯¢åˆ†æµåˆ°è¯»å–å‰¯æœ¬ï¼Œæé«˜äº†æ•´ä½“ååé‡ï¼Œä»è€Œä½¿ä¸»æ•°æ®åº“èƒ½å¤Ÿå¤„ç†æ›´å¤šçš„å†™å…¥æŸ¥è¯¢ã€‚) The sessions implementation ensures sequential consistency for all queries in the sessionï¼Œ no matter what copy of the database each query is routed to. entry.title: How winemakers of color are changing South Africa's wine scene
entry.summary:
South African winemakers are ringing in a new dawn for local viniculture. South Africaâ€™s winemakers of colour are changing the countryâ€™s viticulture, creating a crop of bold new brands.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Pick up almost any bottle of South African wine, and itâ€™s unlikely to have been made by a winemaker of colour. But things are changing. Thereâ€™s an increasing determination to improve opportunities, notably for young South Africans who want to enter the industry. Initiatives such as the Cape Winemakers Guild (CWG) ProtegÃ© programme, which enables newly graduated winemakers from disadvantaged backgrounds to spend time working with some of the countryâ€™s leading winemakers, have benefited several award-winning youngsters. They inclâ€¦

entry.title: Myanmar: UN seeks additional $240 million to bolster earthquake relief
entry.summary: The United Nations is ramping up its response to Myanmarâ€™s devastating earthquake, calling for increased funding and an immediate ceasefire to ensure more aid reaches those in desperate need.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Bombardment, deprivation and displacement continue in Gaza
entry.summary: Hostilities across the Gaza Strip continue to take a devastating toll on the population, with daily reports of Israeli strikes killing and injuring many civilians, UN aid coordination office OCHA said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan faces unprecedented hunger and displacement as war enters third year
entry.summary: The conflict in Sudan has become one of the worst humanitarian crises of the 21st century, leaving millions of women, children and displaced families suffering from violence, food insecurity and the collapse of essential services.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO warns of severe disruptions to health services amid funding cuts
entry.summary: Recent funding cuts have caused â€œsevere disruptionsâ€ to health services in almost three-quarters of all countries, according to the head of the UN World Health Organization (WHO),Â Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Spare developing countries from new US tariffs: UN trade chief
entry.summary: As governments and global markets struggle to deal with the deep concerns and disruptions caused by trade tariffs, Rebeca Grynspan, the head of the UN trade and development agency (UNCTAD), told UN News on Thursday that the poorest countries â€“ whose activities have a negligible effect on trade deficits â€“ should be exempt.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syriaâ€™s political transition at risk due to Israeli military action, Security Council hears
entry.summary: Recent military actions by Israel are undermining Syriaâ€™s political transition and the chances of a new security pact between the two countries, a senior UN official told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Court begins hearing Sudanâ€™s â€˜complicity in genocideâ€™ case against the United Arab Emirates
entry.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Thursday began hearing Sudanâ€™s case against the United Arab Emirates (UAE), which it accuses of being complicit in acts of genocide against the Masalit community in West Darfur by backing the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Preventable â€˜meningitis beltâ€™ deaths targeted in health agency action plan
entry.summary: Millions of deaths could be avoided from meningitis if countries are able to adopt new guidelines designed to diagnose and treat the disease more effectively, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Thursday.

entry.title: Isabel Ravenna
entry.summary: New

entry.title: Why Scotlandâ€™s Argyll & the Isles should be your next getaway
entry.summary:
West of Glasgow, the peninsula of Argyll stretches towards its cluster of neighbouring isles, which fan out in all their marvellous diversity. Although small on the map, this part of Scotland has more than 2,300 miles of coast â€” about as much as South Africa â€” and 23 inhabited islands, each with their own character. After exploring the mainlandâ€™s castles and lochs, head to the fishing port of Oban to fill up on lobsters and mussels. From there, you can depart for an island adventure where you might set forth in a sea kayak, get a taste of the regionâ€™s 24 whisky and gin distilleries, or scale a mighty Munro â€” a mountain that towers above 3,000 ft. From sipping scotch fireside, to navigating wild Atlantic coastlines, hereâ€™s how to explore Scotland's rugged western shores.
Argyll & theâ€¦

entry.title: Love reading? These are the best book towns around the world
entry.summary:
Wigtown, known as "Scotland's Book Town," has a 10-day literary festival every fall. In these small towns from Scotland to New Zealand, books shape identity, tourism, and community. 
In the Welsh village of Hay-on-Wye, where sheep outnumber people and books spill onto the streets, a quiet revolution began. Antiquarian and academic Richard Booth inadvertently launched a global movement when he began filling the empty buildings of Hay-on-Wye with secondhand books.
What started as a single decision in 1961 to fill his sleepy hometown with secondhand books to sell in numerous empty buildings, turned into the birthplace of a global literary mecca uniting villages, bibliophiles, and dreamers alike.Â
People from across the United Kingdom swarmed this small town, and soon boâ€¦

entry.title: Why is everyone looking up in Tucson?
entry.summary:
Nine people are crammed in a tiny room with no ceiling on the grounds ofÂ Kitt Peak National Observatory. Itâ€™s cold. Itâ€™s dark. Each person awaits a turn at the eyepiece of a 20-inch telescope trained on an object. A marbled sphere, swirled in colors of maroon, rust, and cream. Itâ€™s Jupiter, a fellow planet in our solar system, fifth from the sun. â€œLook at that black speck that kinda looks like dirt on the lens,â€ says guide James Schweder. â€œThatâ€™s Io, one of Jupiterâ€™s moons, casting its shadow on the planet.â€ He puts the show in perspective. â€œYouâ€™re basically watching a solar eclipse from more than 417 million miles away.â€Â
With a surfeit of blockbuster attractions as the Grand Canyon, Sedona, Monument Valley and the Hoover Dam in the state, travelers to Arizona can be forgiven for oâ€¦

entry.title: Saudi Arabia's vast desert was once a lush, green paradise
entry.summary:
A new study of stalagmites in caves in central Saudi ArabiaÂ provides strong evidence that the region was lush and green for much of the last eight million yearsâ€”a phenomenon known as â€œGreen Arabia,â€ but until now only a hypothesis.
The study also indicates that the central band of the worldâ€™s â€œbarrierâ€ desertsâ€”Â from the Sahara in the west, across Arabia and to Indiaâ€™s Thar Desert in the eastâ€”were at times well-watered, savannah-like landscapes that encouraged the migrations of primates and other animals out of Africa, including Homo sapiens and some of our hominin ancestors.
â€œThe sand seas that we are used to seeing have not always been the case,â€ says archaeologist Michael Petraglia, the director of the Australian Research Centre for Human Evolution at Griffith University. â€œThatâ€¦

entry.title: Exploring Nova Scotia? These are the towns to visit
entry.summary:
UNESCO-listed Lunenburg remains one of the best-preserved colonial settlements in North America, with around 70% of its original architecture still standing. Nova Scotiaâ€™s cultural landscape is as diverse as its coastline, shaped by Mi'kmaq, French Acadian and African Nova Scotian communities. A coastal road trip, winding along wave-worn cliffs and tranquil, island-studded bays, invites travellers to uncover the rich heritage that runs deep along its shores.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At dawn, mist seeps across the wave-carved headland of Peggyâ€™s Cove, softening the edges of the shoreline and cloaking the whitewashed lighthouse in an ethereal veil. Below, the Atlantic pounds against the granite rocks, sending salt spray into the morning â€¦

entry.title: How these death-defying beetles can help human health
entry.summary:
American burying beetle (Nicrophorus americanus) Scientists are studying the American burying beetle's death-defying resilience to benefit human health.
Among the latest contenders in the fight against drug-resistant infections is a striking, black beetle with fiery red spots and orange-tipped antennae. Known for spending much of its life underground, the little-known American burying beetle could hold the key to developing the next generation of antibiotic treatments.Â
For the past two decades, researchers have investigated how the beetle preserves meat at room temperature, seeking to harness its antibacterial, antifungal, and food preservation properties for human use. Now, scientists have discovered a new super power: These beetles are even resistant to powerful deadly inseâ€¦

entry.title: This strange phenomenon turns the ocean milky whiteâ€”but how?
entry.summary:
â€œIt looked as if we were sailing over a boundless plain of snow, or a sea of quicksilver,â€ writes Captain Kempthorne in his shipâ€™s log.
Sailing a ship called Moozuffer through the Arabian Sea in January 1849, he witnessed something so rare that there are under 400 known records in 400 years and just one photo.
This ghostly phenomenon, called milky seas, has puzzled sailors and scientists for centuries.
After delving into centuries of ship logs like Kempthorne's, eyewitness accounts, newspapers, and satellite imagery, Justin Hudson, PhD candidate at Colorado State University (CSU) and Steven Miller, an atmospheric scientist also at CSU, have published the world's largest database of milky sea observationsÂ in the journal Earth and Space Science.
In it, they write that â€œthâ€¦

Cloudflare Snippets are now generally available (GA) for all paid plansï¼Œ giving you a fastï¼Œ flexible way to control HTTP traffic using lightweight JavaScript 'code rules' --- at no extra cost. Snippets bring the power of JavaScript to Cloudflare Rulesï¼Œ letting you write logic that runs before a request reaches your origin or after a response returns from upstream. Snippets are fastï¼Œ flexibleï¼Œ and freeï¼Œ but how do they compare to Cloudflare Workers? Both allow you to programmatically control traffic. entry.title: GIJN Webinar: Gathering Evidence and Documents in Conflict and War Zones â€” A MENA Case Study
entry.summary: In this GIJN webinar, weâ€™ll explore how investigative journalists can document human rights abuses in war zones, with a focus on methods to ensure the information gathered can later be used by legal investigators or international courts. Drawing from their on-the-ground experience in Syria, Iraq, and Palestine, our expert panel will share practical tools, ethical considerations, and field-tested techniques for recording testimony, analyzing open source material, and archiving evidence in a secure and legally sound manner.

entry.title: This chef is proving Eastern European food is more than cabbage
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
How would you define the cuisine of Eastern Europe?
The tradition of sharing food around the table with multiple generations and passing on stories through recipes is at the heart of Eastern European cuisine. Thereâ€™s also a sense of diversity across cultural and ethnic groups.
In terms of specific dishes, techniques and ingredients, fermentation spans the region. Pies are a simple way of making the most of a few ingredients. And there will always be some form of dumpling. Sour cream is used for stirring into sauces or soups and for dipping dumplings, fritters or pancakes. In summer, thereâ€™s an abundance of herbs â€” dill, parsley, coriander â€” and lots of simple but fragrant spices like caraway, fennel seeds and â€¦

entry.title: S&P 500 Drops and Recoveries, a Long-Term Perspective
entry.summary: Households are seeing the value of their savings decrease significantly over a short period of time. Now seems like a good time to take the long-term point of view. Tags: long-term, stock market

entry.title: San Diego: A culture capital
entry.summary:
When travelers speak of sunny San Diego, they talk about more than the weather. Sure, Californiaâ€™s second-largest city boasts an average of 266 sunny days each year. But San Diego Symphony Music Director Rafael Payare says San Diego residents' infectious optimism and warm disposition also welcome visitors to join in on the good vibes. â€œI am already going into my sixth year with the Orchestra, and being surrounded by the beautiful landscape of San Diego has touched me deeply.â€
With a population of 1.4 million people, San Diego is a bona fide big city with eclectic museums, historic art centers, and world-class performing arts. And yet, its charming neighborhoods and laid-back attitude foster a down-to-earth community vibe. undefined undefined Visitors to the city regularlyâ€¦

entry.title: 10 of the dreamiest stargazing trains in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Each Verde Canyon Starlight train service has a local astronomer on board to help point out constellations and other useful information. From the Nevada desert to the Oregon coast, these heritage railroads allow you to see the stars while rolling through the countryside.
Light pollution is worsening by 10 percent every year, and as our starry skies vanish, so does our connection to the cosmos. But thereâ€™s still an unlikely place for a dark-sky escape: Aboard one of Americaâ€™s historical railways.
A variety of stargazing trains roll through rural landscapes and protected dark-sky preserves where the Milky Way still shines bright, sometimes with a telescope or astronomer on board or an open-air carriage for looking up at the night sky. A train ride offers the perfect chance to slâ€¦

entry.title: This simple doodad is saving our feet on long flights
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
You cross and uncross your legs. You push your personal item to the side. You attempt to use said personal item as an ottoman, but nothing makes the space around your feet comfortable. Except, perhaps, a foot hammock.Â
They may look funky, but these simple slings attach to the tray table on a plane or train to create a suspended foot rest that may help improve circulation and ease lower back pain, according to Amish Dudeja, a Georgia-based foot andâ€¦

entry.title: How to explore Romania's wild Danube Delta by boat
entry.summary:
The marshes along Romaniaâ€™s Danube Delta is particularly popular for hobby fishing. Romaniaâ€™s section of the Danube Delta brims with natural wonders, but Letea Forest, a stretch of the wetland where green woods grow on shifting sand dunes and horses run wild, is especially captivating.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Iâ€™m gliding down a narrow waterway on a small, open-deck viewing boat deep in the marshes. Next to me, wild horses graze on green plains, while on the horizon, ancient woods shimmer in the morning sun. â€œNobody knows how this forest came to be,â€ says local guide and wildlife expert Daniel Petrescu, binoculars in hand.
Having joined a four-day, small-group cruise exploring one of Europeâ€™s largest wetlands, Iâ€™m in Romaniaâ€™s seâ€¦

entry.title: Who should really be allowed to dig for dinosaurs?
entry.summary:
In the 1980s, amateur paleontologists dug up this fossilized jaw of an abelisaurid in Provence, France. The French countryside is rich in fossilized eggs, footprints, and bones. A battle is raging over who is allowed to hunt for them.
One scorching dayÂ last September, Annie MÃ©chin crouched over a slab of red clay on a remote patch of farmland near Marseille, on Franceâ€™s Mediterranean coast. MÃ©chin was scraping away at the clay when she unearthed what looked like a tiny bone fragment. Sensing the familiar jolt of adrenaline that surged anytime she came across a fossil, she called out to her husband, Patrick, who was digging nearby. Carefully, the two amateur paleontologists, both retired and in their 60s, cleared the surface area, dug a small trench around the bone, and fashioned a â€¦

entry.title: Cicadas are backâ€”and this time itâ€™s the â€˜mother of all broodsâ€™
entry.summary:
The last time the periodicalÂ cicadasÂ known as Brood XIV emerged, Netflix was still sending DVDs through the mail, people were buying ringtones for their Blackberries, and Barack Obama was about to be elected president of the United States. Â
Seventeen years later, the world is a very different place. But for periodical cicadas, which spend more than a decade underground as nymphs before emerging in one giant wave as winged adults, itâ€™s business as usual.
â€œBrood XIV is the same brood that was first recorded in 1634 by the pilgrims in the Plymouth colony,â€ saysÂ Gene Kritsky, professor emeritus at Mount St. Joseph College in Ohio, whoâ€™s been studying cicadas for more than 50 years. â€œAnd there it is, still emerging in Plymouth.â€
Of course, it would be another century before â€¦

entry.title: Traveling solo? Here are 7 ideal destinations
entry.summary:
A solo getaway offers the ideal opportunity to immerse oneself in the authentic culture, history, and expression of a particular destination. There are no limits to where inspiration may take you, nor should there be. Whether itâ€™s a Michelin-starred meal or an adrenaline-inducing adventure, with some planning and expert advice, your next solo journey can reach new heights.Â Â
There may be no better combination than a pint and a good bookâ€”and no better destination to imbibe in said lager and literature than Oscar Wildeâ€™s birthplace,Â Dublin, Ireland. Art and cultural historianÂ Dr. Andrew Lear, a scholar of Wildeâ€™s work, suggests a hotel with historical significance. â€œI highly recommendÂ The Shelbourne, where Oscar Wilde stayed when on a speaking tour in Dublin,â€ says Lear.
Leave roâ€¦

entry.title: This animal sanctuary lets you track rare rhinos on foot in Kenya
entry.summary:
Sand sifts through the fingers of Jimmy Lekiondo, a Samburu safari guide atÂ Saruni RhinoÂ who specializes in rhino tracking. It blows to the ground as he scans the trees with squinted eyes. Noticing my curiosity, he whispers,Â â€œRhinos canâ€™t see well but are very sensitive to smell. We do this to ensure they donâ€™t catch our scent.â€Â Motioning for me to follow, he cautions,Â â€œWalk lightly.â€Â Rhinos are also highly sensitive to sound.
â€œThere!â€Â Lekiondo stops and suddenly points. Between the bushes, I see what looks like a giant grey boulder. Then, it moves. A massive southern white rhino stands. Startled by its size, I leap behind Lekiondo, spooking the rhino, which bolts in the opposite direction.Â â€œNever move until I say,â€Â he warns, clearly frustrated. In this environment, following instructâ€¦

entry.title: Why this little-visited South American capital is worth a look
entry.summary:
Plaza Independencia hosts the Artigas Statue near the Ciudad Vieja. The Uruguayan capital flies under the radar, but has an atmospheric old town, a rich musical and literary heritage and beachside barrios to discover.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At first glance, Montevideo has much in common with Buenos Aires, lying on the opposite side of the River Plate. Football, tango and world-class steaks are all found here, though youâ€™re more likely to see Montevideanos strolling around with a mate â€” a herbal tea made from the yerba mate plant â€” than a coffee. But spend some time in the Uruguayan capital, and youâ€™ll soon discover that its draws go far beyond any similarities.
The Ciudad Vieja (Old City) is its oldest and most atmospheric neighâ€¦

entry.title: The best mosquito repellents, from sprays to lotions

As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Mosquito repellents are a great defense for these small but formidable creatures. In addition to causing itching, mosquito bites can transmit diseases like malaria, West Nile, dengue, and chikungunya, according to Richard J. Pollack, Ph.D., senior environmental public health officer at Harvard University.Â
Pollack explains that choosing the right mosquito repellent depends on the person and the circumstances. However, â€œa good repellent can dramaticaâ€¦

entry.title: The shingles vaccine may reduce your dementia riskâ€”here's why
entry.summary:
Shingles, a viral rash, can be incredibly painful. Vaccination can help prevent the infection, but new research is showing the vaccine may also have another benefit: protecting against the development of dementia.
In April, aÂ study published in Nature observed the risk of dementia in adults who received the shingles vaccine versus those who had not. Researchers found that those who were vaccinated against shingles had a 20 percent lower chance of developing dementia. This new evidence is part of a growing body of research linking vaccinations against infections like shingles, the flu, and pneumonia with a reduced risk of dementia, says Paul Schulz, a professor of neurology at UTHealth Houston who was not involved in the study.Â
Approximately one million Americans are diagnosed â€¦

Before any good beach trip, most of us run through a familiar mental checklist: Hat? Check. Sunscreen? Check. Oversized beach bag? Check. But we may not put much thought into beach towels.Â
These days, â€œnot all beach towels are created equal,â€ says Jayme Keffalas, a fashion and travel blogger with The Northern Prepster. Thatâ€™s because beach towels are now made from a variety of high-quality fabrics with features like sand repelling, quick drying, aâ€¦

entry.title: Visiting the Titanic is suddenly a lot easier than you think
entry.summary:
This rendering of the Titanic is based on 715,000 photos and millions of laser scans of the famous wreck, which were stitched together to create a perfect digital replica of what remains of the ship. Fresh advances in 3D scanning technology are making it possible to explore some of the hardest-to-reach and most fragile sites on Earth.
Last year, Parks StephensonÂ stood next to theÂ TitanicÂ and walked slowly around it, gazing up at the massive ship. He paused to look inside one of the boiler rooms and at the position of the controls on the engines. He noticed the number 401, the shipâ€™s ID, etched on the propeller blades. Rusticles hung from the steel shell. Twisted metal and personal trinkets from those long dead littered the ground.
Stephenson, a retired naval officer andÂ Titaniâ€¦

entry.title: 5 ways to explore Tanzania's islands
entry.summary:
With almost 900 miles of tropical Indian Ocean shoreline, Tanzania is as much a coastal destination as it is a safari hotspot. The warm islands sitting off the coast of this East African nation are steeped in heritage, lined with sandy beaches and fringed by coral reefs. Often known as the Swahili Coast, the region is a fascinating swirl of Bantu traditions and Islamic influences. The marine life here â€” which includes whale sharks, a legally protected species in Tanzania â€” is a huge draw for travellers and a natural wonder that locals are working hard to protect. From relaxing on Pemba Island's untouched beaches to wandering the historic streets of Zanzibar, here are five experiences to savour across Tanzaniaâ€™s eastern islands.
For first timers to Tanzania, Jumeirah Thanda Island prâ€¦

entry.title: 7 of the best reef-safe sunscreens
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave NationalGeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
The best reef-safe sunscreens will help protect you from the sun, while keeping reefs safe from chemicals. When news broke back in 2015 that oxybenzone, a common chemical in sunscreens, was incredibly toxic to young coral and other marine life, we all began to look twice at our SPF protection. Since then, more common chemicals in sunscreen formulas have been added to the list of harmful ingredients, and tropical destinations like Hawaii, Aruba, and Key Wâ€¦

entry.title: Sea moss is a billion-dollar health trend. Is it worth the hype?
entry.summary:
Sea mossâ€”also known as Irish moss or Chondrus crispusâ€”is having a social media moment. Celebrities and Tiktokers promote it for everything from better digestion to glowing skin. But is the hype backed by science?
Sold as dried flakes, gels, powders, gummies, and pills, sea moss has become a billion-dollar industry, valued at $2.18 billion in 2024, and the global market is expected to grow to $2.60 billion by 2030, according to Virtue Market Research.Â
But while sea moss is being promoted as a â€œsuperfood,â€ much of what ends up in your supplement bottle barely resembles the raw algae. Carrageenan, an ultra-processed form of sea moss used to emulsify or thicken foods and drinks in the food industry, is stripped of most of the nutrients, including soluble fiber, and may disrupt the gâ€¦

entry.title: Americans Give Early Trump Foreign Policy Actions Mixed or Negative Reviews
entry.summary: More disapprove than approve of leaving the WHO and ending USAID. About half see tariffs on China as bad for the U.S. and them personally, but views differ by party. The post Americans Give Early Trump Foreign Policy Actions Mixed or Negative Reviews appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Unearthing Truths in Turbulent Times: The High Cost of Investigative Journalism in North Africa
entry.summary: Press freedom in the Maghreb is under attack and in decline, but investigative outlets have still found ways to uncover corruption and reduce the risks of publishing.

AutoRAG continuously monitors your data sources and indexes in the background so your AI stays fresh without manual effort. RAG solves this by retrieving relevant information from your data source at query timeï¼Œ combining it with the user's input queryï¼Œ and feeding both into the LLM to generate responses grounded with your data. AutoRAG is built entirely on top of Cloudflare's Developer Platformï¼Œ using the same tools you'd reach for if you were building a RAG pipeline yourself. ğŸ“Š æ–‡ç« ä¿¡æ¯

entry.title: Assistant Professor of Practice in Open-Source Investigative Journalism
entry.summary: The University of Memphis, a vibrant urban public research institution, seeks a dedicated and innovative Assistant Professor of Practice in Open-Source Investigative Journalism in the Department of Journalism and Strategic Media. entry.title: Aid cuts threaten to roll back progress in ending maternal mortality
entry.summary: Unprecedented aid cuts are putting global progress to end maternal deaths at risk, three UN agencies warned in a new report that calls for greater investment in midwives and other health workers.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief urges probe into Russian attack that killed nine children in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights called on Sunday for an investigation into the Russian attack on the Ukrainian city of Kryvyi Rih which reportedly killed 18 people, including nine children.

entry.title: Why you should visit Greece's 'city of gastronomy'
entry.summary:
Thessaloniki's Ano Poli neighbourhood comes alive for lunch time thanks to traditional ouzerias like Tsinari. For two millennia, UNESCO City of Gastronomy Thessaloniki has been celebrated for its food culture, with flavours imported from across Europe, Africa and the Middle East.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The sun has just popped over Thessalonikiâ€™s jumbled rooftops but thereâ€™s already a queue out the door at Bougatsa Bantis. Inside, baker Philippos Bantis is handling the morning rush, bantering with his customers, many of whom he greets by name. It doesnâ€™t take long to get through the orders, since theyâ€™re all for the same thing: bougatsa, the rich, crispy, buttery filo tart thatâ€™s a breakfast staple in Thessaloniki. Traditionally, itâ€™sâ€¦

entry.title: This Thai prison is the best place to get a massage
Heard about The Ghan? Try Australia's other outback train instead
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Three hours: thatâ€™s how long it takes Shelita Buffet to get ready. There are false eyelashes to glue and cheekbones to contour; thereâ€™s a neon-bright wig to preen and a sequined pink leotard to tug on â€” and then thereâ€™s the generous application of glitter to beard. Looking this good takes time. The first honeyed rays of dawn have only just begun to wash into the mining town of Broken Hill and Shelita is standing on the station platform in a pair of blocky white heels, watching as I step off the train.
Iâ€™d boarded in Sydney the day before, leaving behind the skyscrapers and the Opera Houseâ€™s monumental clutch of alabaster shells to make tracks on a journey of continental proportions, rattling east to west across theâ€¦

entry.title: These birds are keeping a record of humanityâ€”one wrapper at a time
entry.summary:
Coots, rotund black waterbirds with big feet, donâ€™t seem like theyâ€™d run the waterways. But in Amsterdam, theyâ€™re the â€œcanal gangsters,â€ territorial and tenacious. They moved in from nearby farms more than thirty years ago, and theyâ€™ve toughed it out even in the dense urban core.
Scientists are researching how coots and other birds adapt to urban environments and whether that move is even a good thing.
Now, a new study unravels thirty years of plastic trash in one of the cityâ€™s biggest coot nests, revealing when coots build and breed in the city.
One particularly large nest documented 30 years of coots living in the red-light district. The oldest item in the nest was a Mars bar advertising the 1994 World Cup; the newest, a protein bar wrapper. Candy packaging, McDonaldâ€™s sanâ€¦

entry.title: How the Portuguese influenced Thailandâ€™s cuisine
entry.summary:
Bangkokâ€™s Kudi Chin neighborhood, in Thonburi on the western bank of the Chao Praya river, is a sleepy one; a jumble of narrow alleys and old houses, some on stilts. It is sometimes called Little Portugal, as it is home to a number of Thais descended from the Portuguese, who had settled here in the late 18th century.
The Portuguese were the first Western nation to contact the ancient Thai kingdom of Ayutthaya in 1511. They soon became a prominent trading partner, and introduced a number of fruits and vegetables, which are now staples in Thai cuisine. As Edward Van Roy writes in Siamese Melting Pot, tomatoes, chillies, peanuts, potatoes, and maize came to Thailand via Portugal. Some of the Thai names for vegetables reflect their imported origin; for example, potatoes are called man fâ€¦

entry.title: The rise and fall (and rise again?) of measles in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Measles cases continue to grow in the United States, which experts link to a rise in personal exemptions for school vaccine mandates. Measles requires 95 percent of a community to be immune to prevent the disease from spreading but the rise of exemptions in some communities has increased their risk of outbreaks.  The U.S. eliminated measles in 2000â€”but that hard-won achievement is now under threat. To contain the current outbreak, some states are following a new playbook to fight the infectious disease.
As the measles outbreak that began in West Texas continues to escalateâ€”with the number of U.S. cases this year now surpassing all those recorded in 2024â€”so does misinformation about how the disease spreads and how to prevent it.
Despite claims from Health and Human Seâ€¦

entry.title: How Hello Kitty helped post-WWII Japan conquer the world
entry.summary:
To much of the world, Hello Kitty is a charming cartoon iconâ€”a blank-faced cat with a red bow and an empire of lunch boxes, backpacks, and billion-dollar branding. But her global rise tells a far more complex story.
Born in 1974 amid Japanâ€™s efforts to recover from the devastation of World War II, Hello Kitty would become an unlikely agent of national reinvention. As the country confronted its imperialist past and sought to repair its international image, a quiet cultural revolution emergedâ€”rooted in the aesthetics of cuteness, or kawaii.
Through Hello Kitty, Japan began to reintroduce itself to the worldâ€”not as a former military power but as a rising expert in soft power.
At the end of World War II, Japan faced a reckoning. The countryâ€™s surrender in 1945 forced its politâ€¦

Since it launched in the early 2000s, GoPro has become synonymous with adventure sports videography. But GoPro cameras can be great tools for capturing unique perspectives on any trip, whether or not youâ€™re paddling Class VI white water or mountain biking downhill at night.Â
With more than 13 generations of cameras, plus tons of accessories, it may be difficult to know which GoPro camera is best for your journey. All GoPros offer not only professioâ€¦

entry.title: Why hikers should ditch the Alps for this mountain range
entry.summary:
Hikers should consider visiting the Carpathian Alps, which includes Romaniaâ€™s Transylvanian Alps, instead of the Swiss Alps. Itâ€™s not only a cost-effective option, but this mountain range has abundant wildlife, cultural sites, quaint villages, and the new Via Transilvanica hiking trail. The Transylvanian Alps provide visitors with abundant wildlife, UNESCO World Heritage sites, and quaint villagesâ€”without the crowds.
Why hikers should try this mountain range in RomaniaHikers pause on a ridgeline trail to look for the perfect selfie shot. Will their backdrop for the Instagram-worthy photo be the snow-dusted peaks or alpine meadows dotted with wild daisies and bellflowers? Meanwhile, below, traditional wooden churches poke through the morning mist; their spires rising above rustic viâ€¦

entry.title: Pakistan's mountains are callingâ€”here's why you should go
entry.summary:
The Karakoram range in Baltistan â€” even at 20,000ft, Laila Peak does not fall into the rangeâ€™s 100 tallest summits. Pakistanâ€™s far north holds some of the worldâ€™s highest peaks and has a proud cultural identity, but until now international visitors have been thin on the ground. A new hiking tour explores a spectacular corner of an often misunderstood country.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Friday prayers have ended, and the streets of Rawalpindi are hot, noisy and rammed. Mopeds growl as they edge through the crowd. In the throng, details catch the eye: henna-dyed beards and candy-striped hijabs; a knife-sharpener showering sparks over the pavement; four passengers and a goat in an auto-rickshaw. Down an alley, boys are playing cricket â€¦

entry.title: Centuries of history reduced to rubble after Myanmar earthquake
entry.summary: This building lies in rubble after a 7.7 magnitude earthquake struck Myanmar on March 28, 2025. Myanmar's Information Minister Maung Maung Ohn announced at a meeting in the capital that 4,589 people were injured and 221 others are missing as of  April 4, 2025. Myanmar's religious temples stood as symbols of faith and history. After the recent 7.7 magnitude earthquake, many are wondering: will they ever rise again or are they lost forever? A catastrophic earthquake shook Myanmarâ€™s northern region on March 28, collapsing historic and religious sites across the country. The 7.7 magnitude quake not only killed moreâ€¦

entry.title: The poison fruit from â€˜The White Lotusâ€™ is real
entry.summary:
Forbidden fruit has been a theme across all seasons of The White Lotus, HBOâ€™s series about a fictional high-end hotel chain. In season three, set in Thailand, the metaphor becomes literal when a hotel worker warns a guest not to eat the fruit of the pong pong tree, as it is toxic enough to kill.Â
Fans of the show are now chattering about whether that deadly narrative seed, planted in the season premiere, will bear fruit in the 90-minute finale as the character Timothy Ratliffâ€™s suicidal ideations continue to escalate.
(Inspired by White Lotus? Here are the Thai islands to visit.)
But what fans might not know is that the pong pong tree (Cerbera odollam) is a real poisonous plant that has been implicated in thousands of deaths a year in the past. The effects of its deadly fruiâ€¦

entry.title: Are tornadoes getting worse? Here's what we know
entry.summary:
Natural disasters like heat waves, fires, and floods are growing more dangerous because of climate change, but the effect a warming world has on tornadoes is complicated and inconclusive.
Thereâ€™s been a recorded increase in the overall number of observed tornadoes since 1950, according to National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration data, but experts say thatâ€™s largely a result of better technology such as Doppler radar. Thereâ€™s been no observed increase in the frequency of major tornadoes over time. Â
But given the pervasive influence of global warming on the atmosphere, it's unavoidable that climate change would impact tornadoes too, said Victor Gensini, an extreme weather expert at Northern Illinois University.
â€œInstead of asking: â€˜Did climate change cause this tornadoâ€¦

entry.title: What to know about tourist visas, and where you can go without one
entry.summary:
U.S. passport holders can travel to more than 120 countries without a visa, including Thailand. So, plan your stress-free trip that includes seeing Wat Chaiwatthanaram in Ayutthaya. U.S. passport holders can travel to more than 100 destinations without a tourist visa, but some popular vacation spots require them. We explain the different types of visas and how to apply.
Avid travelers are always dreaming about the next trip, whether itâ€™s an idyllic family vacation in the Caribbean, a romantic couples trip to Paris, or an immersive culinary tour in Japan. A stress-free journey is always in the forefront of every travelerâ€™s mind when planning a trip.Â Â If you own a U.S. passport, your ease of travel increases.Â Â Â
According toÂ the Passport Index, aÂ U.S. passportÂ currently ranks eiâ€¦

entry.title: Level up your birding with binoculars and spotting scopes
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Itâ€™s no wonder that birdwatching has quickly become a favorite pastime, with one 2022 survey finding three out of 10 Americans taking up the hobby. You donâ€™t need much to get started, other than a sturdy pair of shoes and perhaps a guidebook. However, if youâ€™re planning a wildlife watching tour or want to catch details such as the verdinâ€™s red-dabbed shoulders, you may want to invest in a good pair of binoculars and a spotting scope.Â
Lightweight aâ€¦

entry.title: Are we alone in the universe? These Mars rocks may tell us
entry.summary:
Across the Martian landscape, the view is breathtaking. Everything is quiet, except for a little robot patiently trundling up the sides of Jezero Crater. Perseverance, affectionately known as â€œPercy,â€ doesnâ€™t have the ability to appreciate the reddish-orange hues of the desert landscape like a human can. But the rover has been exploring the red planet since 2021, and itâ€™s been carefully amassing a rock collection that could change our understanding of Marsâ€™ history, how it compares to our own planet, and how we came to be here.
Mars wasnâ€™t always a desolate, dusty world. Scientists think that, at some point in the red planetâ€™s history, it was temperate much like Earth is today. But around three or four billion years ago, Marsâ€™s internal plumbing mysteriously shut offâ€”and as a result, â€¦

entry.title: Gaza: Paramedic still missing after aid worker killings, Palestinian Red Crescent Society calls for answers
entry.summary: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) on Friday called for urgent answers over the whereabouts of a missing paramedic, coupled with a full independent investigation into the killing of 15 humanitarian workers in Gaza on 23 March.

entry.title: World News in Brief: Cholera surges worldwide, DR Congo update, WHO leads global health emergency exercise
entry.summary: A global surge in cholera is threatening vulnerable people from Angola to Myanmar, fuelled by conflict, natural disasters and climate change, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.

entry.title: Appendix A: Demographic makeup of AI experts surveyed
entry.summary: The post Appendix A: Demographic makeup of AI experts surveyed appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: Selected tables by expert and public demographics
entry.summary: Note: We did not receive enough responses from Hispanic or Black experts to be able to report expert views by race and ethnicity; this reflects the racial and ethnic makeup of the field. These groupsâ€™ responses are incorporated into the general figures throughout. We also did not receive enough responses from experts working at nonprofits, [â€¦] The post Appendix B: Selected tables by expert and public demographics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This report is based on a pair of Pew Research Center surveys and a series of in-depth interviews. It draws on a nationally representative survey of U.S. adults who are members of the Centerâ€™s American Trends Panel (ATP), a survey of U.S.-based experts in artificial intelligence (AI) and 30 in-depth interviews with experts who participated [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Public and expert predictions for AIâ€™s next 20 years
entry.summary: We explore how the public and experts anticipate potential positive and negative impacts of AI across key areas of life and society in the coming decades. The post 3. Public and expert predictions for AIâ€™s next 20 years appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online atÂ pewresearch.org/internet. Primary researchers Colleen McClain, Senior ResearcherBrian Kennedy, Senior ResearcherJeffrey Gottfried, Associate Director, Internet and Technology ResearchÂ Monica Anderson, Director, Internet and Technology ResearchÂ Â Â Giancarlo Pasquini, Research AssociateÂ Research team Eileen Yam, Director, Science and Society ResearchAlec [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI
entry.summary: Experts and the public differ in their excitement and worries over AI's increased use, but both share concerns over regulation, misinformation and bias. The post 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI
entry.summary: Experts and the public differ in their excitement and worries over AI's increased use, but both share concerns over regulation, misinformation and bias. The post 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Artificial intelligence in daily life: Views and experiences
entry.summary: As AI becomes part of everyday life, we look at how the public and AI experts experience and view AI, including control of its role in their lives. The post 1. Artificial intelligence in daily life: Views and experiences appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How the U.S. Public and AI Experts View Artificial Intelligence
entry.summary: These groups are far apart in their enthusiasm and predictions for AI, but both want more personal control and worry about too little regulation. The post How the U.S. Public and AI Experts View Artificial Intelligence appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: â€˜Every piece tells a storyâ€™: Bombs to beauty, from Gaza to Ukraine
entry.summary: What happens to bombs after they land? Some explode. Some donâ€™t, leaving behind a deadly legacy of war, but now the remnants of conflict and devastation are being turned into wearable messages of peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Armed violence displaces thousands as cholera outbreak worsens
entry.summary: Ongoing violence in North and South Kivu in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) continues to kill, injure and displace civilians, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Israeli military escalation in Syria, Nicaragua rights probe, South Sudan talks
entry.summary: The UN Special Envoy for Syria has condemned the repeated and intensifying military escalations by Israel in the country, including airstrikes that have caused civilian casualties.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief warns of increasing risk of atrocity crimes in Gaza
entry.summary: The recent killings of 15 medical personnel and humanitarian aid workers in Gaza raise further concerns over the commission of war crimes by the Israeli military, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN envoy urges international support for West Africa and the Sahel
entry.summary: In a briefing to the Security Council on Thursday, the UN Special Representative for West Africa and the Sahel painted a mixed picture of the region, which is facing a growing terrorist threat but also political progress and encouraging initiatives.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar: UN chief calls for urgent access as quake toll mounts
entry.summary: The UN chief on Thursday called for immediate and unrestricted humanitarian access to Myanmar, where last weekâ€™s devastating earthquakes claimed over 3,000 lives and left millions in urgent need of aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: AIâ€™s $4.8 trillion future: UN warns of widening digital divide without urgent action
entry.summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on course to become a $4.8 trillion global market by 2033 â€“ roughly the size of Germanyâ€™s economy â€“ but unless urgent action is taken, its benefits may remain in the hands of a privileged few, a new UN report warns.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan crisis: UN rights chief condemns extrajudicial killings in Khartoum
entry.summary: The fight for Sudanâ€™s capital, Khartoum, likely involved widespread summary executions of civilians following its recent recapture by the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF), UN human rights chief Volker TÃ¼rkÂ saidÂ on Thursday.

entry.title: Who invented sâ€™mores? Forget the mythsâ€”this is the real history
entry.summary:
Dorothy Christian Moore knew the rules when she climbed in the dark to the shipâ€™s bridge. â€œThis is strictly forbidden,â€ she wrote as she crossed the Atlantic Ocean, â€œand I hadnâ€™t been there two minutes before someone seized me roughly from behind.â€ She explained to the officer her pursuit of the sunrise, and together they watched the blue horizon split into silver, then blaze to goldâ€”like so many campfires that would define her years in the United States.
She arrived the next morning at the invitation of the Girl Scouts to spend the summer of 1923 sharing her skills. Her stint as a volunteer in an officerâ€™s hospital kitchen during World War I, feeding 150 men a day, had earned her the affectionate nickname â€œCookie.â€ After the war, she continued in public service as a leader in Girl Guâ€¦

entry.summary: Este comunicado de prensa se ha traducido del inglÃ©s original al espaÃ±ol. En muchos paÃ­ses del mundo, una quinta parte o mÃ¡s de todos los adultos ha abandonado el grupo religioso en el que se criaron. entry.title: How these two vitamin supplements could do more harm than good
entry.summary:
Fat-soluble vitamins, such as vitamin E photographed above, are stored in the body's fat reserves, which is why they have potential to accumulate to toxic levels. Fat-soluble vitamins are more likely to cause adverse effects if consumed in large doses. Hereâ€™s what the experts say about vitamin A and E.
Vitamins and supplements are a booming industry. And while there are many important supplements that benefit people with specific deficiencies or certain health conditions, research shows and experts agree that some synthetic vitamins could cause harms such as liver damage, hair loss, joint and muscle pain, and impaired vision.
"Everyone is always searching for that magic pill that will give them great health, but dietary supplements just aren't it because the benefits often donâ€¦

entry.title: The 'stork sisters' are saving one of India's largest and rarest birds
entry.summary:
Known locally asÂ hargila, the threatened Greater Adjutant stork has found a champion in an unlikely place: the Harglia Army,Â a group of about 20,000 rural women in India turned conservationists. Since 2014, the women have worked tirelessly to give the storks a desperately needed reputational revamp.Â
Once reviled as filthy, adjutants prey on fish, frogs, snakes, rats, and smaller birds like ducks, rummaging through landfills looking for carcasses (hargila translates to bone swallower). Its feeding habits cemented its reputation as unsanitary, a perception that led to a rapid population decline of the adjutant, one of the worldâ€™s largest and rarest storks. Native toÂ India's floodplains in Assam and Bihar, in 2023, it was recently listed as â€œnear threatenedâ€ by the International Union fâ€¦

entry.title: Penguins are insanely resilientâ€”and these explorers are revealing their secrets
entry.summary:
Borboroglu has been an Explorer since receiving the National Geographic/Buffett Award for Leadership in Conservation in 2018. Pablo â€œPopiâ€ GarcÃ­a Borboroglu and Bertie Gregory have been named the 2025 Rolex National Geographic Explorers of the Year.
As a boy growing up in Argentinaâ€™s Buenos Aires Province, Pablo â€œPopiâ€ GarcÃ­a Borboroglu was enchanted by his grandmotherâ€™s tales of her youthful visits to the teeming penguin colonies of Argentine Patagonia. He was a 19-year-old tour guide when he first glimpsed one, and it dawned on him then how important it was to share with others his sense of awe, inspiring them to protect penguins and their habitats.Â
A hemisphere away, Bertie Gregory came to a similar realization as a teenage wildlife photographer roaming the English countryâ€¦

entry.title: Why Florida's greatest family attractions are in the wild
entry.summary:
The observation towers in the Everglades National Park are perfect for taking in Florida's natural beauty. Americaâ€™s sunshine state is a natural playground, with wildlife sanctuaries and conservation-led attractions aimed at families.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Families know what to expect from a visit to Florida, right? Disney World, Universal Studios and other theme parks are the main reason for many visits to the southern state. Yet Florida has a lot more to offer kids on a stimulating, active and even educational family holiday. You can snorkel or try Snuba off the coast, kayak through mangrove channels inhabited by manatees, visit the holiday home of one of the worldâ€™s greatest inventors, explore the Everglades swamps, track dolphinâ€¦

entry.title: How the simple fork almost tore apart the fabric of society
entry.summary:
The dinner fork is one of the most common fixtures at tables worldwideâ€”so ordinary, so unthreatening, that few give it a second thought. But for centuries, the fork was condemned as a symbol of decadence, moral decay, and social arrogance.
Throughout most of history, fingers were natureâ€™s utensils. Knives sliced meat, spoons scooped broth, but only the hand completed the act of nourishment. The fork, however, was something else entirely. â€œThe introduction of the fork reflected and, at the same time, accelerated a series of profound changes in food culture and table habits,â€ says Lucia Galasso, a food anthropologist from Rome. It brought about a more controlled, refined eating processâ€”one that not everyone welcomed.
The forkâ€™s journey from forbidden instrument to universal utensilâ€¦

entry.title: These sea lions aren't 'demonic'â€”they've been poisoned
entry.summary:
Rescuers capture a sick sea lion in Santa Barbara, California. Hundreds of animals have become ill from a neurotoxin, found in algae blooms, that causes concerning behavioral changes. Two beachgoers have been bitten. A common neurotoxin produced by algae blooms is making California sea lions more aggressive. Hereâ€™s why it has the power to change behaviorâ€”and the danger it poses.
Â
RJ LaMendola, a 40-year-old photographer, was surfing north of Los Angeles last month when a sea lion charged at him and bit his backside through his wetsuit. The sea lion stalked LaMendola as he desperately tried to paddle to shore, keeping the board between himself andÂ the animal.Â
â€œI donâ€™t know how to describe the fear that gripped me at that moment, staring into the face of this creature thaâ€¦

entry.title: Here's why pro photographers obsess over this camera bag
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
For seven years, I relied on my trusty camera bag to accompany me to all the remote places around the world where I reported travel and adventure stories. Last year, it finally broke and I discovered that it had been discontinued. That sent me on an unexpectedly trying mission to find an alternative. There are plenty of camera bags, but as an adventure travel journalist and photographer, I couldnâ€™t get just any bag.Â
I needed a weather-resistant caâ€¦

entry.title: Ancient walking trails are backâ€”and you can hike them
The Louvre is a gastronomic journeyâ€”if you know where to look
In Fiji, these hotels put the guests to work (in a good way)
entry.summary: Tourism Fiji's new initiative is rooted in the local concept of loloma, meaning to act with generosity, driven by love, and aims to inspire visitors to help conserve and protect the local flora and fauna. From mangrove nurseries to manta ray protection, these 6 hotels invite guests to help protect the local land and animals. Fijiâ€™s gin-bottle-blue waters, luminous sand, and riotously colorful rainforests have long made it a dream destination. But even paradise needs protection â€” the archipelago faces significant threats from climate change, ranging from rising sea levels encroaching on low-lying habitats to coral bleaching damaging the reefs that sustain marine life and shield shorelines from erosion. Thatâ€™s why hotels across Fiji are inviting guests to be pâ€¦

entry.title: Is this the most beautiful bookstore in the world?
entry.summary:
Luigi FrizzoÂ was warnedÂ that the property he was about to lease could be in a flood zone because of its proximity to the water and rising sea levels in in Venice, Italy. It actually sparked his decision to name his bookstoreÂ Acqua AltaÂ (High Tide).
In addition to coming up with his bookshop's name, Frizzo also took proactive steps to create a flood-proof infrastructure plan to protectÂ more thanÂ 5,000 books, including first editions published more than a century ago.Â He decided to storeÂ hundreds of booksÂ in bathtubs andÂ gondolas,Â longÂ row boatsÂ that have provided transportation throughÂ Venice'sÂ narrow canals since the 11th century.Â
In case you didn't know, Acqua AltaÂ is locatedÂ less than a mile north of Piazza San Marco, the principal public square in Venice. It's easily flooded â€¦

entry.title: Archaeologists found another Egyptian royal tombâ€”but whose is it?
entry.summary:
The discovery of the tomb of an ancient pharaohâ€”the second report in as many monthsâ€”leads a recent spate of archaeological finds from Egypt and casts new light on a formative period of the civilization along the Nile.
In December and January, a team of American and Egyptian archaeologists excavated the roughly 3,600-year-old tomb near the Abydos archaeological site, on the edge of the desert west of the Nile and about 20 miles northwest of the modern city of Luxor in southern Egypt. Egypt's antiquities ministry announced the find in a Facebook post last month.
But the name of the pharaoh who was once entombed there is unknown, as are many of the details about the dynasty of kings he belonged to.
"Egypt was broken apart into multiple rival kingdoms when these kings were rulinâ€¦

entry.title: The day that forced Americans to confront a hidden threat
entry.summary:
FBI agents lead Timothy McVeigh from the courthouse after he was charged with the April 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. McVeigh, who was convicted of the bombing that killed 168 people, wasn't a foreign agent but rather a homegrown terrorist with anti-government views. Itâ€™s been 30 years since Timothy McVeigh bombed the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, an attack that reawakened the nation to the dangers of domestic terrorism.
At 9:02 a.m. on April 19, 1995, a bomb ripped open the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City. The explosion took the lives of 168 people, including 19 young children. It would go down as one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in U.S. history.
It also forced Americans to grapple with an uncomâ€¦

entry.title: Why you should visit Mississaugaâ€”Canada's lakeside city
entry.summary:
While Mississaugaâ€™s sleek yet modest skyline and expansive waterfront might not be as well known as the limelight-stealing attractions of neighbouring Toronto, this attractive city on the shores of Lake Ontario has plenty to offer. As home to the countryâ€™s largest airport, it serves as the entry point for many travellers to Canada, but thereâ€™s much to reward visitors who stick around, with more than 500 wildlife-filled parks, an international food scene and Niagara Falls just across the water, plus a vibrant schedule of year-round markets and festivals. Hereâ€™s what not to miss in Mississauga.
In the heart of the city, Riverwood Parkâ€™s 150 acres features curated gardens blooming with rhododendrons, as well as forests, wetlands and meadows hiding herons, sandpipers, hawks, owls anâ€¦

entry.title: Where to travel in May
entry.summary:
May is the month that signals the start of summer in Europeâ€™s coastal resorts. Summer is on the way, with Europe's beach resorts dusting off their sun loungers, marine life gathering for feeding seasons and a packed programme of seaside festivals and arts events around the world to tempt travellers.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Temperatures in Mediterranean, Aegean and Ionian waters start to rise, many of the regionâ€™s lidos and beach clubs open, and Ibiza's superclub season gets underway with big launch parties.
There are plenty of seaside arts festivals kicking off, too. Notably Brighton Festival (3-26 May 2025) in the UK â€” a mega multi-arts event taking over the Sussex coastal city, with a programme large enough to warrant its own fâ€¦
